where_to_read: IS there any better place to read

reviews.review_text: Great read.  The author will take you on an extraordinary journey.

Living life fully isn't about the comfort of routines, it's about exploring beyond your self-imposed boundaries of daily living, about letting go of presumptions, and learning to be curious in all encounters with others, and with yourself. It's about taking action even when the little voice in your head is urging you to stay complacent.  This book can take you on the journey that you envision, but have never allowed yourself to take.

One of the most boring and absurd books I have ever read, terribly translated and with lots of mistakes. I really had to force myself to continue reading till the end...And I only did because I simply don't leave books unfinished. The pseudo-philosophical attempts and never-ending repetitions were unbearably pathetic.
Interesting topic,  but a little tedious.
This is an anathama, but I prefered the movie.

summary:
Raimund Gregorius teaches classical languages at a Swiss lycée, and lives a life governed by routine. One day, a chance encounter with a Portuguese woman inspires him to question his life—and leads him to an extraordinary book that will open the possibility of changing it. 

Inspired by the words of Amadeu de Prado, a doctor whose intelligence and magnetism left a mark on everyone who met him and whose principles led him into a confrontation with Salazar’s dictatorship, Gergorius boards a train to Lisbon. As Gregorius becomes fascinated with unlocking the mystery of who Prado was, an extraordinary tale unfolds.
